summary: positive-sense RNA viruses encompass one-third of the viral genera. they include numerous pathogens, such as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus, hepatitis C virus (HCV), west Nile virus, Chikungunya virus, and western, eastern, and Venezuelan equine encephalitis viruses. identification of host proteins required for viral amplification would help identify possible targets for antivirals. new antivirals or combination therapies are required for developing effective antivirals. the major obstacle to this approach is our limited knowledge of which host factors are required for viral amplification. the major obstacle to this approach is our limited knowledge of which host factors are required for viral amplification. the viral genome encodes a large polyprotein that is proteolytically cleaved by viral proteases. viral replication occurs in the cytoplasm by synthesis of a minus-strand RNA that is used as a template for synthesis of the plus-strand RNA genomes that are packaged. virions are released following cell lysis (17). heLaUPRT and 911 cells were grown at 37°C and 5% CO2. the cells were supplemented with 1 mg/ml G418 to select for the UPRT gene. titers were determined on either HeLaUPRT (PV) or 911 (adenovirus) cells. the dicistronic reporter was expressed under the control of the simian virus 40 (SV40) promoter. as an additional control for cap-dependent translation, a reporter plasmid was cotransfected with the IRES construct. a total of 5 106 HeLaUPRT cells were either infected with poliovirus (multiplicity of infection [MOI] of 10) or not (mock infected) at 37°C and 5% CO2 in CPBS (phosphate-buffered saline with 0.1 mg/ml MgCl2 and CaCl2) with or without 10 g/ml actinomycin D (Sigma) for 1 h. five micrograms RNA was precipitated with isopropanol, centrifuged at 20,000 g for 20 min. then resuspended in RNA loading buffer (1 MOPS, 10 mM NaOAc, 1 mM EDTA [pH 7.0]) gel was transferred to Hybond N+ membrane (GE Healthcare) and cross-linked to the membrane using a UV Stratalinker 2400. cells were exposed to 365 nm UV for 20 min, followed by lysis (100 mM Tris-HCl [pH 7.5], 500 mM lithium chloride [LiCl], 10 mM EDTA [pH 8], 0.1% lithium dodecyl sulfate [LDS], 1% NP-40, 1% deoxycholic acid [DOC], 5 mM dithiothreitol [DTT], 1 cOm at 5 hpi, cells were cross-linked and RNA-protein complexes were isolated using Dynabead oligo(dT)25 beads (Invitrogen) the proteins were digested in solution with trypsin (Promega), separated by reverse-phase nano-liquid chromatography (nano-LC) using a linear 3-h liquid chromatography (24, 25) using external ontology and gene association annotations. functional network analysis was performed and visualized by STRING (www.string-db.org) and Cytoscape. or control siRNA was [MOI] of 10) or not (mock infected) at 37°C and 5% CO2 in CPBS (phosphate-buffered saline with 0.1 mg/ml MgCl2 and CaCl2) with or without 10 g/ml actinomycin D (Sigma) for 1 h. total RNA was five centrifuged at 20,000 g for 20 min. then resuspended HRP was detected by enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL) Western blotting substrate (Pierce) and autoradiography. after 1 h, the medium was replaced an FB 12 luminometer (Berthold) all assays were measured in duplicate. cells that express uracil phosphoribosyltransferase (UPRT) will incorporate 4-thiouridine (4sU) into all newly synthesized RNAs. UPRT converts 4TU into UMP, which is then converted by cellular kinases to thiouridine triphosphate (4sUTP) RNA from mock- and PV-infected cells was isolated either by TRIzol or by the TUX-MS method. RNA was visualized by ethidium bromide staining of the gel. cells were infected with PV in the presence or absence of 4TU. a viral RNA band appears at 7.5 kb, corresponding to newly synthesized viral RNA (lane 2). Addition of actinomycin D (Act D) inhibits cellular transcription, but not the viral polymerase results in labeling of only the viral RNA (lane 3). if 4TU was omitted from the medium, then no RNA was detected on the Northwestern blot. oligo(dT)25-based capture consistently yielded more cellular mRNAs than uninfected cells. however, RNA extracted by TRIzol consistently yielded equivalent cellular mRNA levels. this difference is due to the significant cytopathic effect by 5 hpi in PV-infected cells. two PV-infected samples were prepared independently for TUX-MS analysis. the PV-infected samples yielded an average of 75 unique peptides. the PV RNA encodes a single polyprotein that is proteolytically cleaved into mature proteins. 3B (VPg), the genome-linked protein, was most likely run off the bottom of the gel due to its small size (3 kDa) however, a single peptide was detected by LC-MS/MS that correspond to a region within 3B. TUX-MS identified peptides that cover all of the viral proteins expected to interact with the viral RNA. whole-cell [35S]methionine-labeled lysates were obtained from mock-infected (lanes 1 to 3) and PV-infected (lanes 6 to 8) cells. asterisks indicate the PV proteins that cross-linked to the viral RNA (lane 5). cellular proteins are known to act as viral RNA-binding host factors for PV. RBP the mass spectroscopy was performed on two poliovirus-infected samples. the data presented represent an average of results between those data sets. e Average fold increase in total spectra for PV-infected versus mock-infected control. most of the identified host factors are RNA binding proteins (RBP) or have RNA recognition motifs (RRMs) the vast majority of the known host factors (Table 2) are either hnRNPs (heterogeneous ribonucleoproteins), nuclear proteins, or proteins that shuttle between the cytoplasm and the nucleus. a similar trend was observed for host factors identified by TUX-MS (36/65). GO clustering analysis of host factors found an enrichment in the coding region instability determinant (CRD)-mediated mRNA stability complex. we identified four out of five members of this complex, DHX9, YBX1, SYNCRIP, and hnRNP U, which is a cytoplasmic RNP that has been shown to control c-Myc stability. eight host factors were chosen for experimental validation from Table 3. for these proteins, we observed efficient knockdown, without an impact on cell viability. the greatest effects on PV amplification (64% and 53% decreases) were observed when CNBP was knocked down. depletion of host proteins found to interact with PV RNA has an impact on PV amplification. cells were transfected with either control or specific siRNAs as indicated. qRT-PCR of mRNA levels following knockdowns normalized to both -actin and GAPDH mRNA levels. poliovirus-infected cells were harvested at 5 hpi and subject to immunoprecipitation with NONO, c-myc, or no antibody (No-Ab). RNA was isolated from input, supernatant (Sup), and immunoprecipitation (IP) identification of NONO by the TUX-MS method suggests that NONO is directly bound to the viral RNA to promote PV amplification. this suggests that NONO directly binds to PV RNA to promote PV amplification. this suggests that NONO is directly bound to the viral RNA. at 4 hpi, two independent siRNAs that target NONO resulted in a decrease in PV amplification. if the titer of virus is determined on cells following NONO knockdowns, then there is a corresponding decrease in plaque number and size. in the absence of the host factors there is a delay in viral production. qRT-PCR was used to determine number of plus-strand (C) and minus-strand (D) RNAs at 4 hpi. mRNA levels after qRT-PCR of mRNA following knockdown were normalized to -actin. Knockdown of NONO had no effect on PV IRES activity. knockdown of PCBP2 and CNBP reduced PV IRES activity by 38% and 26% respectively. results demonstrate a more significant effect on viral replication for NONO than the previously known host factor, PCBP2. this is the first demonstration that PCBP2 is required for mengovirus amplification. however, knockdown of NONO or CNBP did not significantly affect amplification of mengovirus. this suggests that these host factors may be specific to poliovirus or within the Enterovirus genus. RNA from mock- and PV-infected cells was isolated either by TRIzol or by the TUX-MS method. total RNA was visualized by ethidium bromide staining of the gel (bottom) prior to transfer to the membrane. titer was determined by plaque assay. the heterogeneous distribution of mRNA detected by Northwestern analysis. if cells were infected with PV for 5 h, an additional viral RNA band appears at 7.5 kb. addition of actinomycin D (Act D), which inhibits cellular transcription, results in labeling of only the viral RNA (lane 3). oligo(dT)25-based capture consistently yielded more cellular mRNAs than uninfected cells. however, RNA extracted by TRIzol consistently yielded equivalent cellular mRNA levels. this difference is due to the significant cytopathic effect (CPE) by 5 hpi in PV-infected cells. fected and infected samples were used based on the levels of cellular mRNA determined by Northern analysis. proteins were released from purified RNA-protein complexes by digestion with RNase A, digested in solution with trypsin. two PV-infected samples were prepared independently for TUX-MS analysis. 3B (VPg), the genome-linked protein, was most likely run off the bottom of the gel due to its small size (3 kDa) however, a single peptide was detected by LC-MS/MS that correspond to a region within 3B. TUX-MS identified peptides that cover all of the viral proteins expected to interact with the viral RNA. whole-cell [35S]methionine-labeled lysates were obtained from mock-infected (lanes 1 to 3) and PV-infected (lanes 6 to 8) cells. asterisks indicate the PV proteins that cross-linked to the viral RNA (lane 5). cellular proteins are known to act as viral RNA-binding host factors for PV and related viruses. the data presented represent an average of results. c Average number of unique peptides identified by MS. average fold increase in total spectra for PV-infected versus mock-infected control. most of the identified host factors are RNA binding proteins (RBP) the vast majority of the known host factors (Table 2) are either hnRNPs (heterogeneous ribonucleoproteins), nuclear proteins, or proteins that shuttle between the cytoplasm and the nucleus. a similar trend was observed for host factors identified by TUX-MS (36/65). GO clustering analysis of host factors found an enrichment in the coding region instability determinant (CRD)-mediated mRNA stability complex. we identified four out of the five characterized members of this complex, DHX9, YBX1, SYNCRIP, and hnRNP U. 8 host factors were chosen for experimental validation from Table 3. three were identified exclusively in the PV sample and five showed an enrichment in the PV sample. knockdown of heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein L (hnRNP L), ribosomal L1 domain-containing protein 1 (RSL1D1), X-ray repair cross-complementing protein 6 (XRCC6), probable ATP-dependent RNA helicase DDX5, non-POU domain- hnRNP U specifically cross-links to RNA in PV-infected cells. depletion of host proteins found to interact with RNA has an impact on PV amplification. cells were transfected with either control or specific siRNAs as indicated. PV-infected cells were harvested at 5 hpi and subject to immunoprecipitation with NONO, c-myc, or no antibody (No-Ab) RNA was isolated from input, supernatant (Sup), and immunoprecipitation (IP) identification of NONO by the TUX-MS method suggests that NONO is directly bound to the viral RNA to promote PV amplification. this suggests that NONO directly binds to PV RNA to promote PV amplification. this suggests that NONO is directly bound to the viral RNA. negative control, PCBP2 knockdowns triggered a 10- to 30-fold decrease in titers at 4 hpi. at 4 hpi, two independent siRNAs that target NONO resulted in a decrease in PV amplification. if the titer of virus is determined on cells following knockdowns, then there is a corresponding decrease in plaque number and size. qRT-PCR was used to determine number of plus-strand (C) and minus-strand (D) RNAs at 4 hpi. mRNA levels after qRT-PCR of mRNA following knockdown were normalized to -actin. Knockdown of NONO had no effect on PV IRES activity. knockdown of PCBP2 and CNBP reduced PV IRES activity by 38% and 26% respectively. results demonstrate a more significant effect on viral replication for NONO than the previously known host factor, PCBP2. knockdown of NONO or CNBP did not significantly affect amplification of mengovirus. this suggests that these host factors may be specific to poliovirus or within the Enterovirus genus. this suggests that these host factors may be specific to poliovirus. DDX17 is a binding partner and cofactor for zinc finger CCCH-type antiviral protein 1 (ZAP) it targets the RNA of retroviruses, filoviruses, and alphaviruses for degradation (63–65) and potentially poliovirus. the majority of the assayed host factors appear to be enhancers of PV amplification. the majority of the proteins identified by TUX-MS are either nuclear or cycle between the nucleus and the cytoplasm during viral infection. this suggests that TUX-MS is a robust assay to identify host proteins that bind the viral RNA during infection in cell culture. TUX-MS can identify additional host factors with a low false-positive discovery rate even for a well-studied virus, such as poliovirus. spectral counting analysis was used for relative quantification for TUX-MS as it is computationally facile, well suited to detect large differences in relative abundance. one disadvantage is the lack of sensitivity for proteins that generate low spectral counts, or poor ability to be detected by MS. the TUX-MS method could also be modified to be performed without inhibition of host transcription. this would entail labeling of all RNA in the cell with 4sU followed by isolation of the viral RNA-protein complexes using a virus-specific oligonucleotide(s) instead of oligo(dT). TUX-MS could also be expanded to be used on viruses that require host transcription.
